choices.text: Stimulated by decline in serum calcium level
Secreted by endocrine like cells in parathyroid gland
It cannot be administered by oral route

questions.text: Which of the following is true about calcitonin?
questions.solution: Calcitonin is a polypeptide hormone. Oral administration of polypeptide hormone will be ineffective as the polypeptides will be digested in stomach.

choices.text: Less powerful than type I units in action
Need long time to develop tension and long time to return to resting state

questions.text: Following is a characteristic feature of type II motor units
questions.solution: Type II motor units are faster in action, stronger in contraction and more fatigable compared with type I fibres.

questions.text: Reflex response to changes in average skin temperature is
questions.solution: Reflex response to changes in average skin temperature is an anticipatory change and hence it is feedforward mechanism.

questions.text: Receptors belonging to cytokine receptor superfamily are used by
questions.solution: type I cytokine receptor family constitutes receptors for the ligand growth hormone, prolactin, interleukin 6

questions.text: The following is not seen in leptin receptor mutations
questions.solution: Leptin deficiency or leptin receptor mutations leads to variety of hypothalamic abnormalities including  Hyperphagia, Obesity and Central hypogonadism

choices.text: urine excretion equals to around 2 ml/kg/min
urine specific gravity will be more than 2
urine osmolality will be around 50 mosml/L
Excessive reabsorption of water across collecting duct epithelium

questions.text: In the absence of Arginine vasopressin, the following is seen
questions.solution: In the absence of Arginine vasopressin, the urine osmolality will be around 50 mosml/L, a condition called as water diuresis. Urine specific gravity will be around 1.000. Cells of collecting duct becomes impermeable to water

choices.text: Estrogen induced rise in Thyroid binding globulin
Increase in hCG during the first trimester
Increased thyroid hormone metabolism by placenta

questions.text: Total T3 and T4 levels are 1.5 times higher throughout pregnancy. This sustained increase is caused by
questions.solution: Estrogen induced rise in thyroid binding globulin is more of a sustained effect whereas first trimester rise in hCG is a transient effect limited to I trimester only.

questions.text: Glucocorticoid excess is diagnosed using
questions.solution: Glucocorticoid excess is diagnosed using dexamethasone suppression test. ACTH stimulation of cortisol is employed to diagnose glucocorticoid deficiency.

questions.text: Thrombocytosis is associated with
questions.solution: Thrombocytosis is almost always due to iron deficiency, inflammation, cancer, infection (reactive thrombocytosis), and underlying myeloproliferative process (polycythemia vera)

questions.text: Factor binding platelet to sub endothelial vessel structure is
questions.solution:
von Willibrand factor serves two roles in hemostasis

i) adhesion molecule that attaches platelets to the sub endothelial walls

ii) binding protein for factor VIII thereby prolonging the half life of factor VIII

questions.text: Estimating aPTT will provide information about the functionality of
questions.solution: aPTT estimates the intrinsic pathway while PT estimates extrinsic pathway of coagulation

questions.text: Time needed for atrial activation along with AV nodal delay is manifested in ECG by
questions.solution:
Time needed for atrial activation along with AV nodal delay is manifested in ECG by PR interval.

P wave - Atrial depolarization

PR segment - AV nodal conduction + AV nodal delay

questions.text: Duration of cardiac myocyte action potentials is
questions.solution: Duration of cardiac myocyte action potentials is 200-400 msec, while that of neurons and skeletal muscles are 1-5 msec.

choices.text: Speed of cross-bridge cycling between contractile filaments

questions.text: The principal determinant of ionotropic state of heart is
questions.solution: Intracytoplasmic calcium is the principal determinant of ionotropic state of the heart. Positive ionotropic stimuli like sympathetics increase intra cellular calcium to exert its effects.

questions.text: The following influences ventricular afterload except
questions.solution: Atrial contraction influences cardiac preload and not afterlaod.

questions.text: Increase in Myocardial contractility during exercise is is contributed primarily by
questions.solution: Although options B, C and D do influence the increase in myocardial contractility associated with exercise, the increase is more often indirect as they primarily increases the preload and because of preload increase, there is a corresponding increase in cardiac contractility. While the adrenergic excitation of myocardium is more direct way of enhancing cardiac output during exercise.

questions.text: Inflow velocity of blood into ventricles is most rapid during which phase of cardiac cycle?
questions.solution: Inflow velocity of blood into ventricles is most rapid during Early diastole than during atrial systole.

questions.text: In the resting state, much of the acetyl-coA essential for cardiac myocyte ATP synthesis comes from
questions.solution: In the fasted resting state, circulating FFA concentrations and their myocardial uptake are high and they contribute to 70% of hearts' acetyl coA needs

questions.text: Diminution in FEV1/ FVC to what percentage of normal is diagnostic of obstructive lung disorder
The volume at which the outward recoil of chest wall is balanced by the inward recoil of lungs is called
questions.solution: Functional residual capacity is the volume at which the outward recoil of chest wall is balanced by the inward recoil of lungs

questions.text: Following is the principal cause for reduction of expiratory flow in patients with emphysema
questions.solution: reduction of recoil pressure of lungs leading to reduced maximum expiratory flow is the hallmark feature of emphysema

choices.text: Increased blood flow in pulmonary capillaries

questions.text: Respiratory changes not seen in low level exercise is
questions.solution: respiratory adjustments for low level exercises are manifested by increase in depth of breathing and not the rate of respiration. When the increased depth fails to meet the demand, rate then increases

choices.text: Reduced intraluminal gas pressure in airways

questions.text: Increased work of breathing in a patient suffering from covid pneumonia is due to
questions.solution: Work of breathing increases when there is reduced lung compliance or increased airway resistance. Pneumonia increases work of breathing by reducing lung compliance

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in 1st second is reduced

questions.text: Following is a false statement regarding pathophysiology of severe bronchial asthma
questions.solution: Lung compliance is reduced in severe bronchial asthma. with severe airflow obstruction, there will be hyperinflation of lung which reduces compliance

questions.text: In a 54 year old man with crohn's disease confined to terminal ileum, deficiency of which of the following is expected?
questions.solution: The terminal 100 cms of ileum is the only region in small bowel where vitamin B12-Intrinsic factor complex is absorbed.

choices.text: Secreted by parietal cells in stomach
levels are unpredictable in chronic atrophic gastritis
proton pump inhibitors suppress gastrin secretion
High levels of gastrin can lead to peptic ulcers

questions.text: Which of the following is true about gastrin?
questions.solution: G cell hyperplasia and excessive gastrin production leads to hyperstimulation of gastric parietal cells leading to peptic ulcers. seen in Zollinger - Ellison syndrome.

choices.text: Small amounts of gluten can be permitted once symptoms are controlled

questions.text: Regarding the dietary management of proven coeliac disease, select the single most appropriate response
questions.solution: Gluten free diet that excludes wheat, barley is essential in crohn's disease management. Even small amount of gluten is also harmful.

questions.text: Kidneys can not concentrate urine more than the times of palsma osmolality
questions.solution: 4-5 times

choices.text: Efferent arteriole has relatively high resistance
Selective constriction and relaxation of afferent and efferent arteriole

questions.text: Glomerular capillary has comparitively higher pressure than other systemic capillaries because
questions.solution: Selective constriction and relaxation of afferent and efferent arteriole allow highly sensitive control of hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Renal plasma flow is measured by clearance of
questions.solution: Para amino hippuric acid.

questions.text: Role of angiotensin II in kidney is to constrict
Movement of Na across the tight junctions of proximal convoluted tubule is called
questions.solution: Solvent drag is movement of water and solutes across the para cellular pathway without involving epithelial cells

questions.text: A 70 kg weighing individual has a packed cell volume of 45%. calculate his plasma volume?
questions.solution:
Plasma volume = Blood volume/(1-PCV)

normal blood volume is 8% of body weight and hence 5.6L in this individual

Substituting; 5.6 / (1- 0.45) = 3.8 L

questions.text: Transport of small neutral substances across cell membrane occurs by
questions.solution: Small, uncharged, non polar molecules crosses membrane by diffusion

choices.text: Proteins change their charge depending on the region of the cell membrane they are present

questions.text: true statement regarding cell membrane is
questions.solution: Proteins are not a fixed structure in cell membrane. They are constantly moving and this movement is called lateral displacement of proteins. However they do not change their charges according to their places

questions.text: Isoelectric potential for an ion is calculated using
questions.solution: Nernst equation is use to calculate the isoelectric potential of an ion. It is also called as Nernst potential and equilibrium potential

choices.text: All or none phenomena is observed
Conduction velocity is independent of amplitude of action potential
Generation of action potential happen in dendrites

questions.text: True among the following regarding nerve conduction is
questions.solution:
Nerve action potential is all or none in nature

.

questions.text: Nerve conduction is slowest in
questions.solution: delta is the thinnest (sparsely myelinated) of all the options. Diameter of the fibre is directly proportional to conduction velocity. thicker the fibre, faster is the conduction velocity

choices.text: proximal nerve segment including cell body
Entire nerve leaving cell body intact

questions.text: Wallerian degeneration is seen in
questions.solution: In wallerian degeneration, cell body will be spared

questions.text: Tetanic contraction of a muscle is due to accumulation of
questions.solution: Calcium accumulation in cytoplasm leads to prolonged sustained contraction causing tetany

questions.text: To differentiate between sleep and unconsciousness, reversibility of unconsciousness by sensory stimulation is tested. Such sensory stimulation is mandatory in which stage of sleep?
questions.solution: REM sleep is the deepest stage of sleep and that's where sensory stimulation should be at threshold so as to elicit a response

choices.text: Absent gag reflex and cough in response to tracheal suctioning

questions.text: To call it a brain death, these signs must be present except
questions.solution: Abdominal reflex is a spinal reflex. In brain death states, spinal reflexes may be present.

choices.text: Normal EEG in a sedated patient
Normal EEG in a ventilated patient

questions.text: A patient in ICU displays abnormal continuous epileptiform like discharges in EEG. He is confused, disoriented, unresponsive. EEG shows no alpha, beta and gama waves. condition is
questions.solution: Continuous absence of alpha, beta or gama waves indicates that it is not a normal EEG. As there are no motor movements recorded, it can't be myoclonic jerks as myoclonic jerks have normal EEG as well as consciousness. Best answer is B. Non convulsive status epilepticus

questions.text: Brocas area is encoded in
questions.solution: Brocas area is located in left hemisphere; fronto-parietal region.

questions.text: Ascending reticular activating system starting from lower pons connects to
Which of the following finding is characteristic of Argyll-robertson pupil?
questions.solution: Argyll robertson pupil are small, irregular pupils reacting poorly to light. Their response to accomodation and convergence will be normal

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution: gelineau syndrome is narcolepsy. It is not a feature of MS

choices.text: Decreased rate of diffusion of potassium into the cell
Increased rate of diffusion of potassium
Decreased rate of diffusion of sodium into the cells
Decreased rate of diffusion of urea into the cells

questions.text: A drug is administered to a patient, which caused a change in the resting membrane potential of his intestinal epithelial cell to move from -60 mv to -50 mv. Which one of the following finding is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution: As the interior of cell becomes more positive in a non excitable cell like intestinal epithelial cell, there is a reduced gradient for Na to move into the cell from lumen. The increased intra cellular positivity makes potassium to move out of the cell more along its natural gradient. The rate of diffusion of urea would not be altered as urea is a non charged (neutral molecule) solute.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman presents to her ObG consultant for contraception. She has been prescribed with Inj. Medroxyprogestrone (Progesterone hormone). How does the injected hormone is going to act as a contraceptive?
questions.solution: Progesterone in feedback mechanism acts on Anterior pituitary to inhibit the synthesis of FSH. This reduced FSH will lead to underdeveloped Graffian follicle and absent ovulation. Thus causing contraception.

questions.text: A person is about to get operated upon the next day and for that, he has been put on overnight fasting. In spite of that he do maintain a normal blood sugar level. This is made possible by the effect of the hormone adrenaline on beta receptors of skeletal muscle promoting glycogenolysis. What is the effector enzyme coupled to beta 2 receptor to induce this response?
questions.solution: Beta 2 adrenergic receptors are G-Protein coupled receptors and they uses the enzyme adenylyl cyclase to activate second messengers. In this case, activation of adenylyl cyclase leads to generation of cAMP and in turn protein kinse A. This activates phosphorylase kinase and as a result glycogen phosphorylase gets activated leading to glycolysis, increasing
